_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.    Facility accidental release and emergency response policy.

The management and employees of M & M Service Fillmore are committed to the prevention
of any accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Fillmore Fire Department, Montgomery County Local Emergency Planning Committee or other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

     2. The stationary source and the regulated substances handled.

The primary activity at the facility, which is located at 213 South Main St. is the storage of fertilizer for sale to farmers. Anhydrous ammonia is received, stored, and distributed for direct application as a crop production nutrient. The storage and handling system consists of two 18,000 gallon storage tanks, loading risers, associated plumbing and nurse tanks. Access to the site is restricted to authorized facility employees, authorized management personnel and authorized contractors. The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia that can be stored would be 414,500 pounds; this includes the amount of anhydrous ammonia that could be stored in nurse tanks.
   
    3. The worst-case release scenario and the alternative release scenario

This facility has developed a worst-case and alternative-case scenario, however, since this is security-sensitive information it has been withheld from this Executive Summary as required by EPA regulations.

   4. The accidental release prevention program.

This facility complies with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations. This facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1", published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc. as adopted by state regulation and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1

910.111, "Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia". Compliance with these regulations and on-going training of our employees make up our accident release prevention program.
 
  5. Five year accident history. 

On Aug 7th, 2004 we had a release at night caused by vandalism. 580 pounds of anhydrous ammonia was released to the atmosphere. Five people were evacuated from homes nearby as a precaution. There was no damage to persons or the environment. 

   6. The emergency response program.

The facility has a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA standard, 29 CFR 1910.38; provided state and local authorities the emergency planning and community right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA).
In the event of an emergency involving anhydrous ammonia, it is our policy to notify the
Fillmore Fire Department and Montgomery County LEPC and request that they respond to
the emergency. Our emergency action plans have been coordinated with both the fire
department and LEPC.

   7. Planned changes to improve safety. 

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. We have added u-locks to the service valves of our nurse tanks. The facility is well lit at night. Safety inspections on equipment are done on a regular basis. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. There are no specific safety recommendations for implementation at this time.
